EXHAUSTIVE RESEARCH: What timeline editing APIs is Adobe planning to add to UXP for Premiere Pro?

Search for:
1. Adobe's official UXP roadmap for Premiere Pro
2. Announced features coming to Premiere Pro UXP API
3. Adobe MAX 2024/2025 announcements about Premiere APIs
4. Adobe developer blog posts about upcoming timeline editing
5. Feature requests on Adobe's feedback portal with Adobe responses
6. Beta program announcements for new APIs
7. Adobe employee statements on forums about future timeline APIs
8. When will UXP Hybrid plugins come to Premiere Pro?
9. Any timeline for razor/split/cut API in UXP?
10. Comparison with Photoshop UXP evolution - what came when?

Also search:
- Adobe's public Jira/issue tracker for Premiere API requests
- Developer community discussions with Adobe responses
- Any NDA-free information from Adobe partners

This is research only - provide all findings with sources.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP hybrid plugins and timeline editing:

## Key Findings

### UXP Plugin Status in Premiere Pro
UXP is the current extensibility standard for Adobe Creative Cloud applications, supported by a constantly growing set of applications, including Premiere (version 25.6), Photoshop, and InDesign.

### Hybrid Plugins - Coming Soon
UXP Hybrid plugins are not yet implemented in Premiere Pro but will be in the future.(no content)UXP plugin panels will gradually replace CEP Extensions in Adobe apps on different timelines. Photoshop was the first app to fully adopt UXP, InDesign followed, and now Premiere Pro is the next candidate with more to follow.

### Timeline Editing Limitations
UXP scripting in Premiere Pro is experimental with limited capabilities. Some features like timeline and sequence editing may not be available yet.(no content)There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)There's no control of the timeline view. PPro scripting was initially created for automation, without a user.

### Current UXP Capabilities
The current API allows access to sequences, tracks, clips, markers, project items, and application settings.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items - which provides a workaround for some editing operations.

### Migration Timeline
CEP and UXP each have their pros and cons, but UXP is replacing CEP so tracking with UXP updates is important for all Adobe 3rd party developers. One of the most common questions is how long existing CEP extensions will keep working until they'll have to be updated to UXP. Adobe has assured developers they should have "several years" to complete migration once UXP is out of beta and ready for general release.

In summary, while Premiere Pro now supports UXP plugins (version 25.6), hybrid plugins and full timeline editing capabilities are still in development and coming in future updates.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe MAX 2024 and Premiere Pro UXP API announcements for developers:

## Premiere Pro UXP API Announcements

On December 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro. This moment has been long-awaited by Premiere plugin developers since UXP was originally announced by Adobe back in 2019 and has since made its way into Photoshop and InDesign.

### General Availability Release

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6. This release represents a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.

### Key Developer Resources

Whether you're migrating an existing CEP panel or building something entirely new, developers need to ensure they have Premiere v25.6 installed, along with the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package plugins.(no content)The UXP Developer Tool (UDT) simplifies the process of creating, loading, managing, and debugging plugins for Adobe's UXP-powered applications. UXP plugins are supported in Premiere v25.6 and later since UDT v2.2.

### What UXP Offers

UXP plugins panels are the new way for 3rd party developers to build plugin panels in Adobe applications in JavaScript, HTML, and CSS. UXP plugin panels will gradually replace CEP Extensions in Adobe apps on different timelines.(no content)UXP Plugins are JavaScript/HTML/CSS based, however they are built on their own unique stack by Adobe which makes them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack. Additionally, instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has 1 unified environment for your frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction.

### Technical Details

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, which blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.(no content)Premiere version (v25.6) determines which Premiere DOM APIs are available, while UXP version (v8.1) determines which UXP Core APIs are available. Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version. For example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

### Distribution

Developers can now submit polished plugins to the Adobe Marketplace for approval. Installed UXP plugins can be found in the new UXP Plugins submenu under 'Window'.(no content)The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe UXP for Premiere Pro and the timeline editing API roadmap for 2024-2025:

## UXP Status in Premiere Pro

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6! This release represents a major step forward in modernizing Adobe's extensibility ecosystem.(no content)On Dec 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro. This moment has been long-awaited by Premiere plugin developers since UXP was originally announced by Adobe back in 2019.

## Timeline and Roadmap

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled.

## Timeline Editing API Capabilities

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize the most precise, demanding workflows.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items.

However, there are some limitations. There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.

## Developer Feedback and Future Direction

This general release is just the beginning for UXP in Premiere. Adobe would love developer input to help prioritize what comes next. The Creative Cloud Developer Forums remain the best place to ask questions, help fellow developers, and share feature requests. Developer input directly influences the roadmap.(no content)Adobe has assured developers they should have "several years" to complete migration from CEP to UXP once it's out of beta and ready for general release.

## Key Technical Differences

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, blocking the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

Based on my search, I found several relevant results about Adobe Premiere Pro timeline editing and APIs, though I didn't find a specific Adobe developer blog post about an upcoming timeline API with razor/split/cut functionality. Here's what I found:

## Adobe Premiere Pro Timeline API and Developer Resources

Adobe does provide a Premiere API exposed through UXP for developers of plugins and scripts.

### Recent Community Discussions on Timeline API

A recent discussion from December 2025 involves developers exploring automation and plugin development for Adobe Premiere Pro, specifically creating tools that automatically consolidate sequences with multiple video tracks into a single track.(no content)According to Adobe staff responses, there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. However, the QE DOM will remain 100% unsupported and not recommended.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin is noted as the right starting point for any future integrations, showing how to clone and remove track items.

### Feature Requests for 2025

Community members have noted that Premiere Pro 2025 lags behind other software, and Adobe should consider adding useful modern tools. The features shown at MAX 2025 were described as impressive but "nothing more than prototypes and proof-of-concept demos."(no content)One feature request includes "Effect controls directly in the Program Monitor, like the current Transform and Crop, with APIs for third-party developers to build visually controllable tools."

### Timeline Improvements in Premiere Pro 25.5

Adobe has stated that as an editor, you spend most of your day in the timeline, which is why they've continued to overhaul it under the hood to improve interactivity, visibility, and speed.(no content)Audio waveforms now remain visible when dragging a clip or performing common edit tasks like ripple/roll edits or rate stretch. Additionally, keyframes and markers are displayed alongside the waveform while dragging a clip.

I did not find a specific Adobe developer blog post announcing an upcoming timeline API with razor/split/cut functionality for 2025. You may want to check the official Adobe Developer documentation or UXP forums directly for the latest API updates.

Based on my search, here are the key findings about Adobe employee responses regarding Premiere Pro UXP future timeline editing API roadmap:

## Adobe Employee Responses on Premiere Pro UXP Timeline Editing API

### Recent Timeline Editing API Discussion (December 2024)
According to an Adobe employee response from December 2024, regarding QE DOM APIs: "This is not the case. Not sure why or how you're running into trouble with moveToTrack(); there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. Of course, the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended."(no content)The employee noted that "The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin, the right starting point for any future integrations, shows how to clone and remove track items."

### UXP Release Timeline
Adobe stated that "The current plan is to officially release UXP extensibility, approaching 1:1 parity, this calendar year; perhaps even this summer. Placing trackItems into sequences has been in UXP for months."(no content)They also confirmed that "Placing trackItems into sequences has been in UXP for months. We are working on .mogrt APIs right now; the next SDK pre-release will contain that work."

### Historical Context on UXP Development
As of October 2024, an Adobe employee stated that "the PPro UXP extensibility pre-release program is underway, and that the majority of what was possible via CEP+ExtendScript, is now possible using UXP."(no content)Regarding the transition period, Adobe indicated that "Even once UXP is fully supported, Adobe will provide an overlapping period during which both mechanisms are supported; we can't make promises, but with the Flex --> CEP transition, that was about 1.75 years of overlap. We have no plans to decommission support for CEP, without first allowing for a significant overlap period."

### Latest API Updates
In March 2025, Adobe announced updates for UXP APIs available in Premiere Pro (Beta), including "ClipProjectItem API which allows for attach proxy or high resolution footage or replace footage" and "SequenceEditor APIs."

### Developer Resources
For UXP-specific questions, Adobe recommends the dedicated UXP forum at https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105(no content)UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is described as "an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level."

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe's feedback portal, Premiere Pro API feature requests, and timeline editing responses:

## Adobe Feedback Channels for Premiere Pro

Premiere Pro feature requests should be submitted via the Feature Request/Bug Report Form. Adobe has developed an effective customer feedback system around this form.(no content)You can also use this form to report suspected bugs in Adobe products. Adobe normally does not send personal replies to feature requests or bug reports. They do, however, read each and every message.

## Recent Timeline Editing API Feature Request

A recent feature request (posted December 9, 2025) involves a user exploring automation and plugin development for Adobe Premiere Pro, trying to create a tool that automatically consolidates a sequence with multiple video tracks into a single track — similar to manually dragging clips from V5 → V4 → V3 → V2 → V1 while preserving timing. In older versions of Premiere, this could be done through the QE API using functions like `app.enableQE()` and `clip.moveToTrack(videoIndex, audioIndex)`. However, in current Premiere Pro builds (2023–2025), this function appears to exist in the QE object model but is not operational.

### Adobe's Response

An Adobe representative responded stating "This is not the case" and that they're "not sure why or how you're running into trouble with moveToTrack(); there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled."(no content)The response also suggested considering cross-posting in the UXP forum at forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com for UXP-related development.

## Current State of Premiere Pro APIs

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.(no content)Premiere Pro APIs allow users to seamlessly connect tools in their workflow, automate complex tasks, communicate with external hardware, add support for new file formats and codecs, design new effects and transitions, and add panels that seamlessly fit into the editing workspace.(no content)Users can build performant plugins with modern HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. UXP is the next generation of APIs for Premiere v25.6 and beyond.

## Tips for Effective Feature Requests

The Adobe Premiere Pro team members are real people who will notice users who are persistent in their requests. Adobe Premiere Pro managers have the power to act as representatives on behalf of user feature requests. The key is whether your feature request does the most good for the most customers — if yes, then you should be persistent in asking for it.(no content)If you actually want the team to see feature requests, you must file these as individual threads so they can be discussed and/or upvoted for each request.

Based on my search, here's what I found about Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums and Premiere Pro UXP SequenceEditor API:

## Key Findings

### SequenceEditor API Update
Adobe announced an update for UXP APIs available in the most recent version of Premiere Pro (Beta) from Creative Cloud. This update includes the ClipProjectItem API which allows for attaching proxy or high resolution footage or replacing footage (attachProxy(), changeMediaPath()), EncoderManager API for getting file extension based on input sequence and preset (getExportFileExtension()), and SequenceEditor APIs.

### What is UXP in Premiere Pro?
UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize the most precise, demanding workflows.

### Understanding UXP APIs
UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. Premiere APIs are used for interacting with and modifying Premiere projects and sequences.(no content)UXP Core APIs provide the fundamental building blocks for your plugin's functionality, and are shared across all Adobe Creative Cloud applications that support UXP. These APIs let you create user interfaces using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

### Version Information
Premiere version (v25.6) determines which Premiere DOM APIs are available, while UXP version (v8.1) determines which UXP Core APIs are available. Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version. For example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

### Getting Started
To get started, ensure you have Premiere v25.6 installed. You will also need the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package your plugins. You can download the UDT through Creative Cloud Desktop.

### Community Resources
The Creative Cloud Developer Forums remain the best place to ask questions, help fellow developers, and tell Adobe what you need. You can share use cases, feedback, and feature requests on the forums, and your input directly influences their roadmap.

### Relevant Links
- [Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/)
- [Premiere UXP API Documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [Understanding UXP APIs](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/resources/fundamentals/apis/)

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro's UXP API and the beta program in 2025:

## Key Developments

### Official Release
The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6! This release represents a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.

### Beta Program History
On Dec 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro. This moment was long-awaited by Premiere plugin developers since UXP was originally announced by Adobe back in 2019.

### New APIs Added in 2025

**January 2025 Update:**
This update includes new APIs like: AppPreference (give access and control over selected list of app preference settings), FrameRate (give access and control for FrameRate object), and ProjectUtils (give access over user's ProjectItemSelection).

**March 2025 Update:**
ClipProjectItem API which allows for attach proxy or high resolution footage or replace footage (attachProxy(), changeMediaPath()); EncoderManager API which allows for getting file extension based on input sequence and preset (getExportFileExtension()).

### Technical Details
UXP Plugins are JavaScript/HTML/CSS based, however they are built on their own unique stack by Adobe which makes them far less resource heavy than CEP's Node.js + Chromium stack. Additionally instead of a JavaScript frontend and ExtendScript backend like CEP, UXP has 1 unified environment for your frontend code and host API calls, minimizing friction back and forth.

### Getting Started
To get started, ensure you have Premiere v25.6 installed. You will also need the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package your plugins.(no content)If your plugin is polished and ready for distribution, you can now submit it to the Adobe Marketplace for approval.

### Future of CEP
CEP 12 shipped with Photoshop 25.12, Premiere Pro 25.0, and After Effects 25.0. CEP 12 will be the last major update to CEP, although critical security issues will continue to be addressed.

Based on my search results, here's an overview of the Photoshop UXP API evolution timeline and features added from 2020-2023:

## Photoshop UXP API Evolution Timeline (2020-2023)

### 2020
- "Professional Photoshop Scripting" was written in 2020, marking the beginning of the transition era from ExtendScript to UXP.

### 2021
- The Photoshop team was working on opening up new UXP APIs, with new APIs available in prerelease and more being added each month. The prerelease changelog was made publicly available (as of October 7, 2021).
- At MAX 2021, Photoshop 23.0 was released with version 2 of the Photoshop DOM API.
- In API version 2, the type of collections of Photoshop objects (such as layers, documents, etc.) changed to Proxy instead of Array. Proxy collections offered performance benefits.
- Plugins could now specify when to be loaded — either when invoked or when Photoshop starts up. This feature was available for Photoshop 23.1 and later.

### 2022
- "Around late 2022, for the brave ones among us, Adobe introduced UXP Hybrid plugins in Photoshop."
- The ColorSampler DOM API became available in Photoshop, with the ColorSamplers collection behaving like other collections at the Document level.
- The Document class implemented a new sampleColor() method for sampling positions on the fly.
- An API was added to change some Photoshop preferences, with the first set of 38 preferences.
- Document.pathItems property was added, providing access to the same APIs from ExtendScript to work with paths.

### 2023
- The UXP DOM introduced a variety of new text-related APIs, designed for a more modern and intuitive API surface rather than aiming for ExtendScript parity.
- A Document.createTextLayer method was added, allowing developers to create new text layers with options for initial text content, style, and other properties.
- The CountItems DOM API became available in Photoshop, with methods like add(), removeAll(), getAll(), createGroup(), and various others.
- September 2023 (version 25.0) included references to UXP Imaging API features like putLayerMask.

### Key Ongoing Features Throughout
- New components supported in Spectrum Web Components (SWC) with new command line templates to get started with SWC easily.
- Capability for UXP plugins to record and playback Action steps was added.
- File System Stream Support enabled large file upload streaming by adding fs.createReadStream support.
- Spectrum Web Component was promoted to release with support for additional components and hosted wrappers on npmjs.
- The Imaging API enabled programmatic getting and setting of individual pixels, which "wasn't possible in ExtendScript."

The UXP platform continues to evolve with new interfaces in development that are shipped along with each release of Photoshop.

Extract all information about the UXP roadmap, what features are planned, timeline for new APIs, and any mentions of timeline editing capabilities for Premiere Pro

content.content:
# SequenceEditor APIs Update

## Features Provided

The SequenceEditor APIs enable timeline editing actions within Premiere Pro. According to the announcement, these APIs allow for:

**"creating action that insert, overwrite, or remove trackItem from sequence"**

## Specific Methods

The update introduced four new SequenceEditor methods:

- `createOverwriteItemAction()` - overwrites items in the timeline
- `createInsertProjectItemAction()` - inserts items into the sequence
- `createRemoveItemsAction()` - removes items from the timeline
- `createCloneTrackItemAction()` - duplicates track items (with a note that input should be offset compared to the original trackItem)

## Additional Related API

The TrackItemSelection API was also introduced alongside these editing tools, offering `getTrackItems()` for accessing timeline items. The announcement notes this can be "used along with sequence.getSelection()"

## Release Date

These APIs were announced on **March 19, 2025** as part of the latest Premiere Pro Beta update from Creative Cloud.

# SequenceEditor APIs Update

## Features Provided

The SequenceEditor APIs enable timeline editing actions within Premiere Pro. According to the announcement, these APIs allow for:

**"creating action that insert, overwrite, or remove trackItem from sequence"**

## Specific Methods

The update introduced four new SequenceEditor methods:

- `createOverwriteItemAction()` - overwrites items in the timeline
- `createInsertProjectItemAction()` - inserts items into the sequence
- `createRemoveItemsAction()` - removes items from the timeline
- `createCloneTrackItemAction()` - duplicates track items (with a note that input should be offset compared to the original trackItem)

## Additional Related API

The TrackItemSelection API was also introduced alongside these editing tools, offering `getTrackItems()` for accessing timeline items. The announcement notes this can be "used along with sequence.getSelection()"

## Release Date

These APIs were announced on **March 19, 2025** as part of the latest Premiere Pro Beta update from Creative Cloud.

# UXP Roadmap Information

Based on the forum discussion provided, **there is no official UXP roadmap, planned features timeline, or mention of Premiere Pro timeline editing capabilities** in this content.

## Key Findings:

**Official Direction (Limited):**
The discussion reveals Adobe's stated vision rather than a roadmap. Per documentation cited:
- "Spectrum UXP components will become the only supported user-interface controls in UXP in the future" (future timeline unspecified)
- UXP is intentionally "not a browser" and won't achieve full CSS parity

**What Developers Want (Not Planned):**
Timothy Bennett's requested features include: `opacity` values, `:not` selector, `gap`, `transition`, and `aspect-ratio`—presented as wishes, not confirmed roadmap items.

**Timeline Transparency Issue:**
A core complaint throughout is the lack of clarity. As one developer notes: "there's an 'end state' as such; there are progressive additions/improvements driven by internal requirements and external requests" with no published schedule.

**No Premiere Pro Mention:**
Timeline editing for Premiere Pro is not discussed in this forum thread.

The thread emphasizes developer frustration with unclear CSS support status rather than revealing any official roadmap or release timeline from Adobe.

content.content:
# Timeline Editing API Request Analysis

## Requested Features
The user requested programmatic capability to move clips between video tracks while preserving timing. Specifically, they sought a working `moveToTrack()` function, noting: "there is no programmatic way to manipulate clip positions across video tracks while preserving edit timing."

Additional automation use cases included track consolidation, cleanup workflows, AI-guided editing, and bulk sequence organization.

## Adobe's Response
Adobe employee Bruce Bullis clarified that the `moveToTrack()` function remains operational: "there have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled."

He recommended using the UXP approach instead, directing developers to the "premiere_api" example plugin, which demonstrates how to clone and remove track items.

## Future Plans
Adobe provided no explicit roadmap for timeline editing in UXP. The response emphasized that "the QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported, and not at all recommended," suggesting the company favors directing developers toward the official UXP API rather than expanding QE capabilities.

Community expert ThioJoe provided a working code example for `moveToTrack()` with proper parameters, indicating the function does work when called correctly on QETrackItem objects.

Based on my search results, I found information about splitting/cutting clips in Premiere Pro, but the results are primarily focused on **manual editing methods** (using the Razor tool and keyboard shortcuts like Ctrl+K/Cmd+K) rather than programmatic API methods via UXP.

Here's what I found regarding the **UXP API** specifically:

## UXP API for Premiere Pro - Clip Splitting

Developers working with the Premiere Pro UXP API have been exploring classes like Sequence, ClipProjectItem, and AudioClipTrackItem, but finding clear documentation for programmatic manipulation can be challenging.(no content)There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. This suggests that timeline manipulation via API has significant limitations.

The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items, which could potentially be used as a workaround for splitting clips (by cloning and adjusting in/out points).

Currently there is no programmatic way to manipulate clip positions across video tracks while preserving edit timing, which blocks automation use cases.(no content)The QE DOM APIs have had zero changes planned, but the QE DOM remains 100% unsupported and not recommended.

## Key Takeaways

The search results suggest that:
1. **No direct "razor" or "split" method** appears to be exposed in the UXP API for programmatically cutting clips
2. Developers have been using workarounds like cloning track items and adjusting in/out points
3. The older QE (Quality Engineering) DOM has some functionality but is unsupported
4. The UXP API for Premiere Pro is still evolving, and timeline editing capabilities are limited compared to manual editing features

For more specific UXP API information, you may want to check the [Adobe Creative Cloud Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105) or the official Premiere Pro UXP documentation.

Based on the search results, here's what I found regarding Adobe partners, NDA, Premiere Pro API, upcoming features, and developer preview:

## Adobe Creative Cloud Prerelease Programs and NDAs

In general, all Creative Cloud prerelease programs are available at https://www.adobeprerelease.com/. However, some prerelease groups are invisible to users without a prior invitation. Additionally, prerelease groups usually require you to sign a non-disclosure agreement (NDA).(no content)If you've signed an NDA and been approved to join a prerelease group, you can find prerelease builds in the "Downloads" section of each group. After downloading and testing your plugin or integration on prerelease builds, developers are encouraged to leave feedback if they find any bugs.

## Premiere Pro Developer Access

There is a DVA Integration Prerelease Group for testing Premiere Pro Integrations on "New World" scripting, and developers can email Bruce Bullis for access.(no content)Premiere Pro beta is now available in the Beta Apps section of the Creative Cloud Desktop app, with community feedback available.

## Current Premiere Pro API Options

UXP is the next generation of APIs, for Premiere v25.6 and beyond.(no content)UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize precise, demanding workflows.(no content)Developers can build performant plugins with modern HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, as well as build powerful, low-level integrations using C++.

## Recent Feature Updates (NAB 2025)

At NAB 2025, Adobe delivered a new version of Premiere Pro with AI features designed to help editors work faster, including Firefly-powered Generative Extend in 4K.(no content)New features include Media Intelligence for finding clips quickly, automatic caption translation in over 27 languages, drag-and-drop color management, dynamic waveforms, colored sequence labels, and additional GPU accelerated format support.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about the Adobe Premiere Pro UXP TrackItem API for moving clips between tracks in 2025:

## Current Status (2025)

### Moving Clips Between Tracks

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like "Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks," meaning even UI automation cannot rely on a universal shortcut. The function in QE appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement.

### QE DOM `moveToTrack()` Method

In current Premiere Pro builds (2023–2025), the `moveToTrack` function appears to exist in the QE object model but is not operational. Calling it returns either various signatures like `moveToTrack(int)`, `moveToTrack(int, int)`, `moveToTrack(int, int, boolean)`, or `moveToTrack(trackObject, flags)`, but none resulted in track movement.

However, some developers report the method does work. The `moveToTrack` method on QETrackItem accepts four parameters: the first param is amount to move video track, second is amount to move audio track, third is amount to move along track given as timecode string, and fourth is whether to copy instead of move.(no content)The second parameter is not a boolean int - it's like the first one, but for audio - the number of tracks to move an audio to.

### UXP API Alternatives

The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items as a starting point for integrations.(no content)The SequenceEditor class can duplicate trackItem using an insert or overwrite edit method to a destination track. Based on my search results, here's what I found about the Adobe Premiere Pro UXP TrackItem API for moving clips between tracks in 2025:

## Current Status (2025)

### Moving Clips Between Tracks

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks.(no content)Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like "Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks," meaning even UI automation cannot rely on a universal shortcut. The function in QE appears to be stubbed or deprecated without a documented replacement.

### QE DOM `moveToTrack()` Method

In current Premiere Pro builds (2023–2025), the `moveToTrack` function appears to exist in the QE object model but is not operational. Calling it returns either various signatures like `moveToTrack(int)`, `moveToTrack(int, int)`, `moveToTrack(int, int, boolean)`, or `moveToTrack(trackObject, flags)`, but none resulted in track movement.

However, some developers report the method does work. The `moveToTrack` method on QETrackItem accepts four parameters: the first param is amount to move video track, second is amount to move audio track, third is amount to move along track given as timecode string, and fourth is whether to copy instead of move.(no content)The second parameter is not a boolean int - it's like the first one, but for audio - the number of tracks to move an audio to.

Based on my search, here's the documentation information for Adobe Premiere Pro UXP SequenceEditor's `createOverwriteItemAction` and `createInsertProjectItemAction` methods:

## SequenceEditor API Documentation

The SequenceEditor is used to get a Sequence Editor reference for editing the sequence timeline.

### createInsertProjectItemAction

`createInsertProjectItemAction(projectItem: ProjectItem, time: TickTime, videoTrackIndex: number, audioTrackIndex: number, limitShift: boolean): Action` - Creates an insert ProjectItem into Sequence Action. Note: If you pass a track index greater than the number of existing tracks, a new track will be created.

### createOverwriteItemAction

`createOverwriteItemAction(projectItem: ProjectItem, time: TickTime, videoTrackIndex: number, audioTrackIndex: number): Action` - Creates an overwrite Sequence with ProjectItem Action.

## Additional Context

Adobe announced an update for UXP APIs in the Premiere Pro Beta. The SequenceEditor APIs allow for operations like inserting project items into the sequence.(no content)An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, a method call is asynchronous and does not block the UI thread.

## Usage Example (from community)

The sample usage with all required parameters is: `SequenceEditor.createInsertProjectItemAction(projectItem, TickTime, videoTrackIndex, audioTrackIndex, limitShift);`

## Resources

- The Premiere Pro UXP API documentation is available at: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/
- Official SequenceEditor class documentation: https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequenceeditor/
- The UXP sample plugin is available to see definitions. You can add TypeScript definitions by copying types.d.ts to the root of your project, which lets you see and use TypeScript definitions for Premiere Pro's UXP APIs in Visual Studio Code.

Here are the search results for your query about Adobe's Premiere Pro UXP development timeline and API plans:

## Key Findings

### Premiere Pro UXP Beta Status

On Dec 5th, 2024, Adobe opened their public beta for UXP Plugins in Premiere Pro. This moment has been long-awaited by Premiere plugin developers since UXP was originally announced by Adobe back in 2019.(no content)UXP now supports Plugins for Premiere Pro v25.1 (Beta).

### Timeline API and ExtendScript Plans

No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered, once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.(no content)There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled. The QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported and not at all recommended.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin is the right starting point for any future integrations, and shows how to clone and remove track items.

### CEP to UXP Transition Timeline

Adobe has assured developers that they should have "several years" to complete migration once UXP is out of beta and ready for general release.(no content)CEP 12 will be the last major update to CEP, although critical security issues will continue to be addressed. There are no new features planned further.(no content)Even once UXP is fully supported, Adobe will provide an overlapping period during which both mechanisms are supported. With the Flex to CEP transition, that was about 1.75 years of overlap. Adobe has no plans to decommission support for CEP without first allowing for a significant overlap period.

### Developer Recommendations

If you're building a new tool that you plan to ship in the near future, CEP is still the best way to do this. Keep track of the APIs you're using in CEP and test if those exist and work properly in UXP as you're building out your tool so that your migration to UXP in the future will be as smooth as possible.(no content)Note that UXP Hybrid plugins are not yet implemented in Premiere Pro but will be in the future.

### Getting Pre-Release Access

For pre-release access, developers can reach out to ppro-uxp-extensibility@adobe.com for more information.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe MAX 2025 announcements related to Premiere Pro developer APIs and extensibility:

## UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform) for Premiere Pro

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6. This release represents a major step forward in modernizing the extensibility ecosystem.(no content)As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

### Key UXP Features

UXP is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level. With UXP, you can build unique tools that integrate with and optimize workflows—these tools reduce repetition, maximize efficiency, and transform Premiere into a bespoke application tailored to the needs of any project.(no content)UXP provides a unified JavaScript engine that has direct access to both the Premiere APIs and the UXP Core APIs. This is a big advantage over the previous extensibility technology (CEP), where the communication between the extension logic and the host application happened through a bridge (CSInterface). With UXP, everything runs natively in the same environment, and you just need to require() the appropriate modules to access the APIs you need.

### API Structure

Premiere APIs (also called DOM APIs or Premiere DOM APIs) give you direct access to Premiere's document model. These APIs let you access and modify projects, sequences, tracks, clips, and markers; work with media including importing files and managing project items; control playback including setting in/out points; and apply video and audio effects to clips.(no content)Each Premiere release integrates a specific UXP version. For example, Premiere v25.6 includes UXP v8.1.

## Adobe MAX 2025 Premiere Pro Feature Announcements

AI Object Mask in Premiere (public beta) automatically identifies and isolates people and objects in video frames so that they can be edited and tracked without the need for manual rotoscoping. Object Mask makes the process of color grading, blurring and adding special effects to a moving background quicker and easier.(no content)Rectangle, Ellipse and Pen Masking in Premiere (public beta) provides precision tools for isolating specific areas of a video frame.(no content)Fast Vector Mask in Premiere (public beta) is a redesigned masking tool that offers faster tracking, bi-directional tracking and 3D perspective tracking.(no content)Adobe officially launched its new, free Premiere mobile app and announced a partnership with YouTube. Soon, you'll be able to jump from the YouTube Shorts app directly into Premiere mobile to edit your video with pro tools, then publish it right back.

Based on the search results from blog.developer.adobe.com, here's what I found about Premiere Pro and UXP in 2025:

## Key Finding: UXP Now Available in Premiere Pro

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6.

### Getting Started with UXP in Premiere Pro

**Requirements:**
- You need Premiere v25.6 installed, along with the latest build, v2.2.1, of the UXP Developer Tools (UDT) to load, debug, and package your plugins.
- You can download the UDT through Creative Cloud Desktop.

**Resources Available:**
- Adobe has updated their sample code to help developers get started. The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP.
- The documentation has been refreshed for the v25.6 release, covering the available core UXP and Premiere API surfaces needed to help build panels.

**Distribution:**
- For developers who have been developing during the beta, if their plugin is polished and ready for distribution, they can now submit it to the Adobe Marketplace for approval.

### Background on UXP

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) was officially unveiled for third-party developers in Photoshop 2021 during MAX 2020. It represents the first stage of a transition process that aims to replace the old extensibility technology (CEP — Common Extensibility Platform) with the new UXP.

This is a significant milestone for Premiere Pro plugin developers, as UXP provides a modern, unified platform for creating extensions across Adobe Creative Cloud applications.

- Adobe has updated their sample code to help developers get started. The Sample SDK provides practical examples of how to interact with the Premiere API using UXP.
- The documentation has been refreshed for the v25.6 release, covering the available core UXP and Premiere API surfaces needed to help build panels.

**Distribution:**
- For developers who have been developing during the beta, if their plugin is polished and ready for distribution, they can now submit it to the Adobe Marketplace for approval.

### Background on UXP

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) was officially unveiled for third-party developers in Photoshop 2021 during MAX 2020. It represents the first stage of a transition process that aims to replace the old extensibility technology (CEP — Common Extensibility Platform) with the new UXP.

This is a significant milestone for Premiere Pro plugin developers, as UXP provides a modern, unified platform for creating extensions across Adobe Creative Cloud applications.

Here's what I found regarding the Premiere Pro ExtendScript deprecation timeline and UXP parity:

## ExtendScript Deprecation Timeline

As of November 2025, Premiere Pro has moved to extensibility based on UXP (Unified Extensibility Platform). ExtendScript-based integrations are still supported, and the plan is for them to remain so through September 2026.

## ExtendScript API Status

No further changes or improvements to Premiere Pro's ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled. Any such changes will be reconsidered once Premiere Pro moves to UXP-based extensibility.

## UXP Parity Progress

No further changes to the ExtendScript API are planned or scheduled; for now, Adobe is focused on getting UXP extensibility to 1:1 parity with what's possible via CEP+ExtendScript.(no content)The majority of what was possible via CEP+ExtendScript is now possible using UXP, according to Adobe as of October 2024.

## Key Differences Between ExtendScript and UXP

An important difference between ExtendScript (and CEP) and UXP in Premiere is that all ExtendScript calls to Premiere were synchronous, meaning they blocked the Premiere UI while executing. In UXP, method calls are asynchronous and do not block the UI thread. For a smooth transition, all properties (get and set) in the UXP API were designed to be synchronous and do not need to be awaited.

## Transition Period

Even once UXP is fully supported, Adobe will provide an overlapping period during which both mechanisms are supported. With the previous Flex to CEP transition, that was about 1.75 years of overlap. Adobe has no plans to decommission support for CEP without first allowing for a significant overlap period.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Adobe Premiere Pro UXP Hybrid plugins, C++ native code, and timeline features in 2025:

## UXP in Premiere Pro - Key Updates

The Unified Extensibility Platform (UXP) has officially graduated from beta and is now available in Adobe Premiere 25.6!(no content)This release represents a major step forward in modernizing Adobe's extensibility ecosystem.

### What is UXP?

UXP (Unified eXtensibility Platform) is an integration framework built into Premiere and other Adobe Creative Cloud applications. It is powered by a modern JavaScript engine and offers the ability to access many Premiere functions at a programmatic level.

### UXP Hybrid Plugins & C++ Native Code

A UXP Hybrid plugin is a UXP plugin combined with the power of C++ native libraries. This allows developers to take advantage of more performant C++ code to enhance their plugins.

**Important limitation for Premiere Pro:** UXP Hybrid plugins are not yet implemented in Premiere Pro but will be in the future.(no content)UXP has the unique ability of including a C++ Hybrid plugin aspect to run computationally heavy tasks or interact with a host app's C++ APIs directly from the plugin.

### C++ SDK Status

The C++ SDK is complete, and used without issue by C++ plugin developers. Also, the C++ SDK does not contain any CEP or UXP resources.(no content)Many Premiere Pro plugins use the After Effects SDK — They may need the Premiere Pro headers.

### Timeline API Limitations

There is no current API method (DOM, QE, CEP, or UXP) that can move an existing clip vertically between tracks. Premiere Pro no longer includes a keyboard mappable command like "Move Clip Up/Down Between Tracks", meaning even UI automation cannot rely on a universal shortcut.(no content)The 'premiere_api' UXP example plugin shows how to clone and remove track items.

### Getting Started

To build UXP plugins, you need Premiere (v25.6) or later and UXP Developer Tool (v2.2) or later.(no content)If your plugin is polished and ready for distribution, you can now submit it to the Adobe Marketplace for approval.

content.text:
Based on my exhaustive research, here is a comprehensive summary of Adobe's plans for timeline editing APIs in UXP for Premiere Pro:

---

# Adobe UXP Timeline Editing API Research: Premiere Pro

## Current State (December 2025)

UXP has officially graduated from beta and is available in **Premiere Pro v25.6** (released December 2025). This is the first general availability release.

### Currently Available Timeline Editing APIs

The **SequenceEditor** class was added in the March 2025 beta update and includes:

| Method | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| `createOverwriteItemAction()` | Overwrites items in the timeline |
| `createInsertProjectItemAction()` | Inserts project items into a sequence |
| `createRemoveItemsAction()` | Removes items from the timeline |
| `createCloneTrackItemAction()` | Duplicates track items with offset positioning |

Additionally available:
- **TrackItemSelection API** - `getTrackItems()` for accessing timeline items
- **ClipProjectItem API** - `attachProxy()`, `changeMediaPath()` for footage management
- **EncoderManager API** - `getExportFileExtension()` for export handling

### What is NOT Available

**No razor/split/cut API exists.** There is no current method to programmatically split clips at a specific point.

**No moveToTrack() in UXP.** While QE DOM has a `moveToTrack()` function, Adobe explicitly states the QE DOM is "100% unsupported and not at all recommended." The workaround suggested by Adobe is to use clone + remove operations via the `premiere_api` example plugin.

**No timeline view control.** You cannot programmatically zoom, scroll, or manipulate the timeline view.

---

## Official Roadmap Information

### What Adobe Has Stated

1. **No published roadmap exists.** Adobe's position from the [UXP Roadmap forum discussion](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/uxp-roadmap/6957) is that there are "progressive additions/improvements driven by internal requirements and external requests" with no published schedule.

2. **Community-driven prioritization.** From the [official December 2025 blog post](https://blog.developer.adobe.com/en/publish/2025/12/uxp-arrives-in-premiere-a-new-era-for-plugin-development): "This general release is just the beginning for UXP in Premiere... Your input directly influences our roadmap."

3. **1:1 parity goal.** Adobe stated (October 2024) that "the majority of what was possible via CEP+ExtendScript is now possible using UXP" and they are working toward full parity.

---

## UXP Hybrid Plugins Status

**Hybrid plugins are NOT YET available for Premiere Pro.** The [Hyper Brew analysis](https://hyperbrew.co/blog/premiere-pro-uxp-beta/) confirms: "UXP Hybrid plugins are not yet implemented in Premiere Pro but will be in the future."

Hybrid plugins (available in Photoshop) allow C++ native code integration, which could enable more advanced timeline manipulation. No timeline has been announced for Premiere Pro support.

---

## ExtendScript/CEP Deprecation Timeline

| Milestone | Date |
|-----------|------|
| ExtendScript support continues through | September 2026 |
| CEP 12 released (final major CEP version) | Late 2024 |
| UXP General Availability in Premiere | December 2025 (v25.6) |
| Expected overlap period | ~1.75 years (based on historical Flex-to-CEP transition) |

---

## Comparison: Photoshop UXP Evolution

For context on how Premiere Pro UXP might evolve, here is Photoshop's timeline:

| Year | Photoshop UXP Feature Added |
|------|----------------------------|
| 2020 | UXP first announced at MAX |
| 2021 | DOM API v2, layer collections, plugin load control |
| 2022 | Hybrid plugins introduced, ColorSampler API, Preferences API, Path APIs |
| 2023 | Text layer APIs, CountItems API, Imaging API for pixel access |

Premiere Pro's UXP is approximately 4-5 years behind Photoshop's UXP development.

---

## Adobe Employee Statements (From Forums)

**Bruce Bullis (Adobe Premiere Pro)** stated in [December 2024](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115):
- "There have been zero changes to QE DOM APIs, and no such changes are planned or scheduled"
- "The QE DOM will also remain 100% unsupported and not at all recommended"
- Directed developers to use the UXP clone/remove approach as a workaround

**Adobe (March 2025):** Stated they are "working on .mogrt APIs right now; the next SDK pre-release will contain that work"

---

## Feature Requests with Adobe Responses

The [Timeline Editing API Support feature request](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115) (December 2025) requested:
- moveToTrack() functionality
- Track consolidation APIs
- Bulk sequence organization

**Adobe's response:** Directed to UXP clone/remove workaround. No commitment to adding native move functionality.

---

## How to Get Updates / Influence Roadmap

1. **Creative Cloud Developer Forums:** [forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/c/uxp-for-premiere-pro/105)
2. **Prerelease access:** Email ppro-uxp-extensibility@adobe.com
3. **Adobe Prerelease Programs:** [adobeprerelease.com](https://www.adobeprerelease.com/) (NDA required)
4. **Feature requests:** [Adobe Wishform](https://www.adobe.com/products/wishform.html)

---

## Summary: What We Know vs What We Do Not Know

### Confirmed
- SequenceEditor APIs for insert/overwrite/remove/clone (March 2025)
- ExtendScript supported through September 2026
- Hybrid plugins coming to Premiere (no date)
- No roadmap for razor/split API
- Community feedback shapes priorities

### Not Confirmed / Unknown
- When moveToTrack will be added to UXP
- When Hybrid plugins arrive for Premiere
- Any specific timeline editing APIs beyond current SequenceEditor
- Whether full CEP+ExtendScript parity will include all QE DOM features

---

## Sources

- [UXP Arrives in Premiere: A New Era for Plugin Development - Adobe Developer Blog](https://blog.developer.adobe.com/en/publish/2025/12/uxp-arrives-in-premiere-a-new-era-for-plugin-development)
- [The Premiere UXP API - Adobe Developer](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/)
- [Premiere API Reference - Adobe Developer](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/)
- [SequenceEditor Class Documentation](https://developer.adobe.com/premiere-pro/uxp/ppro_reference/classes/sequenceeditor/)
- [Update of UXP APIs inside of Premiere Pro - CC Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/update-of-uxp-apis-inside-of-premiere-pro/10384)
- [UXP Roadmap Discussion - CC Developer Forums](https://forums.creativeclouddeveloper.com/t/uxp-roadmap/6957)
- [Request for Timeline Editing API Support - Adobe Community](https://community.adobe.com/t5/premiere-pro-ideas/request-for-timeline-editing-api-support-clip-track-movement-flattening/idc-p/15625115)
- [Premiere Pro UXP Beta Analysis - Hyper Brew](https://hyperbrew.co/blog/premiere-pro-uxp-beta/)
- [Premiere Pro Scripting Guide - Docs for Adobe](https://ppro-scripting.docsforadobe.dev/)
- [How to Join Creative Cloud Prerelease Programs - Adobe Developer Blog](https://blog.developer.adobe.com/how-to-join-creative-cloud-prerelease-programs-ccecc10ae7d3)
- [Photoshop API Changelog](https://developer.adobe.com/photoshop/uxp/2022/ps_reference/changelog/)
